Pepper__bell___Bacterial_spot.description: Bacterial spot on bell pepper causes small, dark, water-soaked lesions that may have a yellow halo. It can lead to premature leaf drop.
Pepper__bell___Bacterial_spot.treatment: Use copper-based bactericides. Avoid overhead watering. Remove and destroy infected plant debris.

Pepper__bell___healthy.description: Your bell pepper plant is healthy with vibrant green foliage and no visible symptoms of disease. The leaves are firm and have a high saturation of green.
Pepper__bell___healthy.treatment: Continue regular maintenance, ensuring proper drainage and adequate sunlight. Consistent watering is key.

Potato___Early_blight.description: Early blight causes dark brown spots with concentric rings (bullseye appearance) on older potato leaves.
Potato___Early_blight.treatment: Apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil or mancozeb. Rotate crops annually.

Potato___Late_blight.description: Late blight is a devastating disease causing dark, water-soaked lesions that turn brown-black quickly in humid conditions.
Potato___Late_blight.treatment: Apply copper-based fungicides immediately. Destroy infected plants to prevent spread.

Potato___healthy.description: Your potato plant is healthy. The leaves are firm and evenly green.
Potato___healthy.treatment: Ensure consistent watering and hilling to protect developing tubers.

Tomato___Bacterial_spot.description: Bacterial spot causes small, dark, circular spots on tomato leaves, often with a yellow halo.
Tomato___Bacterial_spot.treatment: Apply copper sprays. Avoid working with plants when they are wet.

Tomato___Early_blight.description: Tomato early blight shows up as brown spots with rings. It usually starts on the lower leaves.
Tomato___Early_blight.treatment: Remove lower leaves to increase airflow. Apply appropriate fungicides.

Tomato___Late_blight.description: Late blight on tomatoes causes large, irregularly shaped dark spots and can rapidly kill the entire plant.
Tomato___Late_blight.treatment: Use preventive fungicides. Remove infected plants immediately. Avoid high humidity.

Tomato___Leaf_Mold.description: Leaf mold appears as pale green or yellow spots on the upper leaf surface with olive-green mold on the underside.
Tomato___Leaf_Mold.treatment: Improve greenhouse ventilation. Reduce leaf wetness. Apply fungicides if severe.

Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.description: Septoria causes numerous small, circular spots with dark borders and grey centers.
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.treatment: Apply fungicides. Mulch around the base of plants to prevent soil splash.

Tomato___Spider_mites_Two-spotted_spider.description: Spider mite damage appears as fine yellow stippling on leaves. Silk webbing may also be visible.
Tomato___Spider_mites_Two-spotted_spider.treatment: Use insecticidal soap or neem oil. Increase humidity around the plant.

Tomato___Target_Spot.description: Target spot causes brown spots with distinct concentric rings, similar to early blight but more circular.
Tomato___Target_Spot.treatment: Ensure proper spacing for airflow. Use fungicides as needed.

Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.description: This virus causes severe stunting, upward leaf curling, and yellowing of leaf margins.
Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.treatment: Control whitefly populations (the primary vector). Use virus-resistant varieties.

Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.description: Mosaic virus causes mottling, distorted growth, and yellow/green patches on leaves.
Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.treatment: There is no cure for viruses. Remove and destroy infected plants. Wash hands after handling.

Tomato___healthy.description: Your tomato plant looks great! It's healthy, strong, and ready for a good harvest.
Tomato___healthy.treatment: Continue regular pruning, watering, and staking for the best results.
